title: Synthetic Recap
body:
SAN ANTONIO — In a season defined by its methodical, physical nature, the Houston Rockets delivered a masterclass in dominance, dismantling the San Antonio Spurs 103-79 on the road. But this was no ordinary team victory; it was a canvas for one of the most breathtaking individual performances in NBA history, as Hakeem Olajuwon authored a night for the ages.

Olajuwon was simply unstoppable, pouring in a career-high and franchise-record 51 points. The Spurs threw every defender they had at “The Dream,” but his array of post moves, turn-around jumpers, and commanding presence in the paint rendered them all helpless. He was a force of nature, scoring at will and controlling the tempo of the entire game from the low block.

While Olajuwon’s scoring was historic, his all-around dominance was equally impressive. He corralled 14 rebounds and was a defensive menace, swatting away 4 Spurs shots and anchoring a Rockets defense that held San Antonio to a paltry 79 points.

The Spurs, led by 21 points from Vinny Del Negro, simply had no answer. The game was a one-sided affair from the start, with Olajuwon’s relentless attack demoralizing the home team possession by possession. Clyde Drexler provided capable support for Houston with 16 points, but on this night, he was a brilliant secondary option to the main event.

The final buzzer signaled more than just a win; it signaled a historic achievement. Olajuwon’s 51-point eruption was not merely a statistical anomaly, but a performance of sheer will and artistic brilliance, a signature moment from one of the game's all-time greats that left an indelible mark on the 1997 season.
